chapter.chapter: Salvation — Divine Exchange or Divine Participation?
chapter.tagline: Revealing that Jesus didn’t substitute man’s place but included man in His death and resurrection.

questions.q: What is the difference between divine exchange and divine participation?
questions.a: Divine exchange teaches substitution — Jesus took man’s place. Divine participation reveals identification — man died and rose with Christ. The believer’s salvation isn’t a swap but a shared life.

questions.q: Did Jesus die for us or with us?
questions.a: He died both for us and with us. His death was representative, yet inclusive — our old man was crucified with Him so that we could share His new life.

questions.q: Why is substitution not the full picture of salvation?
questions.a: Substitution only handles punishment; participation produces transformation. The cross removed sin’s penalty, but participation in Christ’s resurrection made us new creations.

questions.q: How does divine participation affect the believer’s nature?
questions.a: Through participation, the believer becomes one spirit with the Lord. Salvation is not God tolerating a sinner — it’s God reproducing Himself in man.

questions.q: Is salvation just forgiveness of sins?
questions.a: Forgiveness clears the record; salvation recreates the man. The goal of the cross was not pardon but regeneration — bringing man into the God-kind of life.

questions.q: What happens if one believes only in the substitution aspect?
questions.a: He may live forgiven but powerless. Full salvation experience begins when one believes he died and rose *with* Christ — sharing in His righteousness and dominion.
